column8: content
request stock assessments of billfishes; believes responsible rec fishing is important for tourism and economic benefits to member countries should be recognized

intro letter requesting observer status; The principal purpose of PITIA is to organize the Pacific Islands commercial tuna industry to be a more effective player in regional fisheries management and development issues…it is noted that WCP Fisheries Management Convention provides for special consideration to be accorded to the development needs of the small Pac Is states...

In order to link Reponsible Fisheries with Respinsible Markets, apply a marketing certificate, exclusive for every boat included in the RFMO Registry with a cood standing, compulsory for the commercialization of tuna products:
intro letter requesting observer status;
intro letter requesting observer status
Emphasize close scientific collaboration between Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission & WCPFC and alignment of management efforts b/w RFMOs

intro letter requesting observer status; The purpose of my attendance would be to meet participants and talk with them about our program as a prelude to us taking a more active involvement in the region in coming years.
doc summarizing Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission measures (incl. area closures to control YFT/SKJ PS bycatch of BET and catch limits for BET

A seabird Conservation Measure based on the recommendation from the WCPFC Scientific Committee would be a highly constructive step to reduce seabird bycatch in the WCPFC area; provide doc reviewing potential measures (practical/on-water) for dealing w/bird bycatch
substantial recs re: most aspects of WCPFC fisheries, attach companion report on allocation esp. re: SIDS: https://www.wcpfc.int/system/files/World Wildlife Fund-TRAFFIC%20ALLOCATION%20paper.pdf

Greenpeace presented a statement on behalf of Birdlife International, EII, World Wildlife Fund, Blue Ocean Institute and the HumaneSociety, which supported the implementation of precautionary measures for target tuna resources and bycatch species in the WCPF Convention Area.
requests WCPFC consider econ and socially important rec fishery; also suggests including spatial management component; offer of assistance re: catch data sharing/cooperation

emphasis on ALB: supports the international management of albacore in a sustainable manner, based on the best scientific data…believes that ALB resources which visit carious countries' EEZs should be managed so national measrues are consistent and compatible with internationall agreed measures for the HS

other mgmnt measure: establish no-take marine reserve for species under the competance of the WCPFC in the enclosed HS area bounded by Palau, FSM, PNG and Indonesia; ask for 100% observer coverage for entire convention area and centralised tamper-proof VMS for all vessels; ban on all at-sea transshipments; 50% reduction in effort across entire WCPO sector (based on 2001-2004 levels)

In light of the recommendations of the Scientific Committee to reduce BET F by 25% and YFT by 10%; in order to achieve the proportional fishing mortality reduction for the purse seine fishery, WTPO propose that WCPFC could establish a time and area closure on FADs fishing by all purse seine vessels, in areas, and during the time where more juvenile bigeye and yellowfin concentrate as best way of reducing juvenile tuna mortality

support scientific rec of 39% reduction in BET F & 26% in YFT F; see CDS as key priority for WCPFC; want HS transshipment ban; FAD closures to compat juv BET and YFT bycatch; sanctions against IUU vessels; improved observer coverage ; emphasis on allocation process

discusses IUU fishing and finning of sharks by EU fleets; wants National Plan of Actions for sharks; landing sharks with fins attached; 0 catch policy for endangered sharks; ban on shark discards and limit bycatch of all shark spp.; scientific assessments of all commercial shark spp.

excluded (actually dated 2011 - organizational error on website): highlights much of UNCLOS text in relation to WCPFC fishing activities; advocates for ban on all drfit/gill net fishing and manufacturing; asks for $1 million fine to any IUU HS drfit net fishing vessel; asks for WCPFC to help establish and encourage an international troll fishing association

Stalling tactics by certain distant water fishing nations (DWFNs), and other difficulties in reachingconsensus within the WCPFC, have led to a very non-productive and damaging process andlack of progress, where key conservation and management measures are not agreed; call for cessation of fishing in HS in areas bounded by Pacific Island states (first step to ward no-take marine reserves); 50% reduction in tuna fishing effort across entire WCPO; banning of all at-sea transhipments; permenant ban on FADs; ammend CMM 2007-3 to eliminate loopholes for IUU

support spatial and temporal closures (3-month FAD closure and 3 month PS closure on HS); want 100% coverage for all fishing vessels - proposed timeline for implementation; want WCPFC to introduce eCDS

column2: International Union for the Conservation of Nature
column8: International Union for the Conservation of Nature provides guidance and support to UN countries, and can therefore bring any importantissues to the attention of the UN on behalf of WCPFC ... supports: well considered decisions in relation to CMMs for turtles, sharks, YFT and swordfish; reduction in total catch of BET by 30% as recommended by scientific committee

spatial management should be taken into consideration. IGFA would be pleased to consult and advise member states on the economic important of rec fishing and the related tourism that it creates…requests that your statistics and scientific reports reflect the effort on the stocks targeted by rec fisheries incl. all marlins

The Director shall continue efforts to promote compatibility between the conservation and management measures adopted by Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission and WCPFC in their goals and effectiveness, including by frequent consultations with his counterpart in WCPFC, so that they can maintain, and inform their respective organizations of, a thorough understanding of conservation and management measures directed at bigeye, yellowfin, and other tunas, and the scientific bases and effectiveness of those measures.

Developed Dolphin Safe brand; we believe that time and/or area closures can provide a means to reduce bycatch of non-target species, such as sharks, billfish, sea turtles and other species, while allowing fishermen to continue to harvest tuna at sustainable levels. We encourage the Commission to take steps to experiment with such closures to ensure protection for the ocean ecosystem.
50% reduction in effort across WCPO (in line with BET scientific advice); closure of 4 HS pockets; ban on all at-sea transshipments; permanent ban on FADs

column2: International Union for the Conservation of Nature
column8: call for listening to SC and reduce BET catch; want agreement on CMMs around spp. bycatch; want closure of 4 HS pockets to make them MPAs/eliminate IUU; call for removal of all fishing subsidiesby the governments of the major fishing nations, which allow their fishing fleets to fish'profitably' here in the Pacific.

call for committee to follow advice of SC w/ implementation of 43% reduction in BET F, reduction in PBT juvenile F; wants independent review of WCPFC performance; 100% observer coverage; calls for CDS for BET by 2011; recommends the WCPFC set biological reference points for the stocks it manages incl. sharks
statement about shark CMMs: ask for inclusion of additional spp. in CMMs; prohibit removal of fins at sea; set catch limits for sharks; prohibit landing of ecologically vulnerable spp.

reduce effort by 50% across region; implement HS pocket closuresto address IUU; year-round ban on FAD fishing; Support Canada’s proposal on establishing a formal process that NGOs can submit; WCPFC member countries would be wise to embrace the demand for sustainable products and enforce policies that meet the standards of the market place compliance information to the Technical and Compliance Committee.

reduce BET F; FAD closure; identify non-compliance with data reporting; member countries to sign PSMA; require vessels to have IMO number for tracking; tackle IUU through continued HS closures; highlight needs of small-scale fishers in region

urge the WCPFC to formally adopt reference points...call on the WCPFC to adopt harvest control rules that are well-defined, preagreed and contain mandatory actions for an agreed and determined course of management action in response to changes in indicators of stock status with respect to reference points.; 100% observer coverage (all vessels and gears); stringent penalties for infractions/failure to comply with CMMs

mentions recent Marine Stewarship Council certification and need for biological ref points for ALB; urge the WCPFC, Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission, and coastal states to work together to develop an effectiveIUU monitoring and enforcement system

believes target and limit ref points should be set for ALB; wants more life history research and more frequent stock assessments; worried about catch and effort limits across ALL GEARS (given low impact of ALB troll fishery)

extend HS closures to all types of fishing; adopt 2 additional HS pockets; support Parties to the Nauru Agreement proposal to close HS to PS; ban PS on whale sharks; adopt year-round ban on FADs; reduce F BET 50%; reduce YFT catch; precautionary limits for SKJ; reduce overcapacity and transfer current capacity to SIDs; set limit and ref points; agree on process that allows greater involvement of NGOs in MCS activities incl allowing them to submit info on con-compliance w/ CMMs

call for improved assessments of shark pops; measures aimed at mitigating impacts on sharks (esp. whitetip, blue, whale); urge requirement of fins-attached reg; on-water recs for hook types and fishing behaviour modifications to limit shark bycatch

call for total PS closure instead of just FAD closures; improved moniutoring of transshipments; vessel registry and capacity limits (develop record of fishing vessels with IMO #s w/ limited entry); regs around shark finning; prohibit PS from setting on whale sharks; ask for biological reference  points for target stocks
against driftnet fishing for ALB; call for complete ban on driftnet fishing

extend FAD closure to end overfishing of BET; increase observer coverage to 100%; maintain HS pocket closures; establish and adopt target and lim ref points; strengthen complience for CMMs; prohibit retention of certain shark spp; mandate gear modifications; prohibit PS from setting on whale sharks; improve Port-State measures to deter IUU; require UVIs for all vessels

call for harvest control rules (as they are related to Marine Stewarship Council scheme) + biological ref points (target and limit) for 4 key tunas; reduce F for BET & PBT & YFT; 100% observers; supports SIDS to stengthen ALB LL mgmnt to address overcapacity; want CDS; mitigation of key bycatch spp.

re: impact of S PAC TROLL ALB fleet: This fishery has zero effects on the albacore stocks in the South Pacific, and is totally separate from the longline fishery in the areas of both amount of catch and age class it catches. It would be a shame to divide up the fishery in some sort of catch share scheme that may be appropriate for the longline fleet but not for the albacore troll fleet.

supports International Seafood Sustainability Foundation advocy to reduce capacity in tuna fleet; states that Contrary to various information being circulated, catches of sea turtles in tuna purse seine nets is minimal; states that shark bycatch still accounts for 1% of PS bycatch - requires no shark finning and live release; It is our view that, in conjunction with restrictions to reduce overfishing and release live bycatch, FAD fishing can be considered a sustainable fishing method. We support studies, including those currently being conducted by the International Seafood Sustainability Foundation, tofind ways to reduce bycatch when using FADs... We support trial efforts of FAD-free tuna fishing operations so long as they are undertaken by companies that fully adhere to our non-encirclement Dolphin Safe policy...FAD-free fishinghas other environmental consequences, such as an increased carbon footprint due to the need for boats to travel longer distances to find schools of tuna and potential effects on fish species used as bait. FAD fishing, which should be closely regulated is expected to continue to be a sig. part of canned tuna supply as bait. FAD fishing, which should be closely regulated, is expected to continue to be asignificant part of canned tuna supply

premanent closure of HS pockets; total ban on FADs; ban on at-sea transshipments; ban on PS fishing on whale sharks; no effort increase in ALB; adopt precautionary ref points for all tunas; all sharks to be landed with fins

develop HCRs and ref points for all stocks; address fleet overcapacity by adopting closed vessel registry (esp. for PS) + transfer mechanisms for SIDs; est. rules for monitoring and managins fishing capacity through the convention area; require IMO #s; improved FAD mgmnt incl. FAD activity and catch logbook; prohibit at-sea removal of shark fins; prohibit PS sets on whale sharks; stock-specific ref points for sharks + more robust bycatch measures for silky + whitetip spp.; limit LL capacity in WCPO

limit FAD use to catch fewer juvenile BET; expand HS closure; establish target and limit ref points for all spp; catch limits for PBT; increase transparency of ISC; finning ban; mandate on-water bycatch mitigation methods; no PS on whale sharks; improve FAD mgmnt; improve PSM to deter IUU; require IMO #s for vessels > 100 t; strengthen transhipment controls to comply with VM rules

calls for adoption of B and F-based ref points for all stocks + precautionary approach in interim; science-based harvest strategies for all stocks; consider vessel day scheme specific to HS closure areas; reduction in BET FADs; limits on PS effort; reduce LL BET F; PS closure for BET during time of highest juvenile bycatch; limit YFT F; keep juvenile F for PBT below 02-04 level; introduce effort controls for ALB; encourage domestic managerts to implement Tuna Msmnt Plans that reeze licenses; ref points for non-target spp.; do not PS on whale sharks; prohibit retention of certain shark spp; implement fins attached policy; adopt turtle CMMs and new gear to reduce bycathc; adopt seabird CMM recommended by ACAP and modify on-water practices; eCDS; revise observer program; ensure burden of proof is on IUU vessel; oppose implementation of observer fee; re HCR: The measure wasalso specifically included in the Food and Agriculture Organization of UN Code of Conduct for Responsible Fisheries, serving as a guidepost forsustainable fisheries management. Furthermore, the measure appears prominently in the Food and Agriculture Organization of UN Guidelines forecolabelling, and is a critical element for consideration in ecolabelling certification schemes such as the MarineStewardship Council (Marine Stewarship Council).

major areas of concern: 1 - improvements in observer health, safety and welfare; 2 - forstering the developing observer professionalism; 3- appropriate use of eclectronic monitoring; the APO remains very concerned regarding continued reports ofthreats, intimidation, harassment, and bribery of observers serving on vesselsoperating in the WCPFC Convention Area - offer specific ways in which WCPFC could improve (e.g Observer Bill of Rights and training)
ban intentional PS on whale sharks (proposal by Australia signed by other WCPFC members)

summarizing new listing of shark spp. and need for collaboration w/ RFMOS: The interaction of CITES with regional fisheries management organizations such as WCPFC has taken on new significance with the CITES listing of several shark species, that fall underthe purview of the Commission...The collaboration between CITES authorities and fishery agencies at national and regional levels will be essential for the effective implementation of these requirements, and this willneed to get assistance where required.

The position of the U.S. South Pacific albacore troll harvesters remains firm. There is no scientific or economic basis to close the high seas to the South Pacific albacore troll fishery. This fishery occurs entirely outside of any of thePacific Island Countries’ EEZs.

immediate cap on LL and PS vessels to limit capacity; target and lim ref points for all spp.; ban at-sea transshipments; moratorium on PBT fishing until stock has recovered; halt effort increased in ALB fishery; closure of 4 HS pockets; implement revised vessel day scheme; year-round ban on FADs; ban on FADs; ban on LL wire tracers; better shark bycathc mitigation measures and development of ref points; agree to cap the number of longline andpurse seine vessels in the fishery and prioritise the development of a clear, time-bound planto assess and eliminate overcapacity in the WCPO that takes into consideration social andenvironmental criteria for reducing overcapacity in tuna fisheries; be more transparent in meetings (feel there are increasing # of closed sessions and docs unavailable before meetings)

reduce F for striped marlin; stock assessments for billfish spp.; ban on Pacific billfish entering into intl. trade; require countries to report dead discards and use circle hooks in LL fisheries; adopt rebuilding plan for PBT (and ban comm. fishing until in place); establish allocation keys; elimiante FADs in BET PS fishery; lower LL catches for BET; no shark fins removed at sea; strengthen controls against IUU

In2012, theWCPFC adopted limit reference pointsfor skipjack, bigeye, yellowfin and South Pacific albacore. This was an important first step.Now the WCPFC needs toadopttarget reference points for these same stocks.; address overcapcity by establishng limited entry via comprehensive closed vessel registry; freeze in PS capacity w/ mechanism to transfer capacity from developed to aspiring nations; require IMO #s; better FAD mgmnt and data collection; urges members to adopt comprehensive and robust CMMs for sharks (silky and whitetip); limit LL capacity to address transshipment problems; urges for CMS meting reform for better transparency (by allowing observers)

require VMS on all vessels; ban LL transshipping (unless 100% observer coverage onboard); all vessels out of compiance with transshipment put on IUU list; heavy fines for IUU vessel owners and flag states

end overfishing of BET by freezing fleet capacity; limit FADs; increase observer coverage; develop rebuilding plan for PBT; require IMO # on vessels in convention area; develop regional scheme of PSMs; ban on HS transshipments; prohibit retention of whitetip sharks; memebr countries to supply FAD data to commission

develop target and lim ref points + harvest control strategy for all stocks; adopt PBT recovery plan; further monitoring and research of FADs; comprehensive shark CMM to mandate bycatch practices; binding and consistent standards for observers; required CDS that includes transshipment measures and PSMs and trade restricutions for IUU countries

column2: Secretariat of the Pacific Regional Environment Programme
column8: re: non-target bycatch: Efforts made to promote protection and conservation within EEZs can be nullified unless similar measures are taken on the high seas....SPREP has been working closely with several of its member countries to improve the protection afforded to a number of shark species in the region through the Convention on Migratory Species and the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species.; concerned about marine debris and impact of drifitng FADs on turtles; supports the establishment of large and small MPAs; highlghts problem of climate change and its impact on Pac Island states: SPREP will continue to be strongly engaged in developing a monitoring network for ocean acidification within the Pacific Islands region, and welcomes the support of Pacific Island governments, members of the Commission, regional organisations and other stakeholders in this initiative. Pacific Island nations are uniquely dependent on the Ocean, and can rightly claim to be at the forefront of global efforts to improve sustainable management and conservation of marine resources.

The commission can't afford to be the ambulance at thebottom of the cliff, and must develop precautionary targets and harvest control rules to restore all the fisheries in its mandate to full health and productivity; ensure full compliance with data provision req'ts for all CCMs and decreaased fishing opportunities for those that fail to comply; adopt TRPs and LRPs (interim) until final agreed no later than 2017; moratorium on target PBT fishing; new recovery plan for BET; CMM for ALB to reduce capacity; strengthen response to non-ompliance and IUU fishing by adopting Compliance Monitoring Scheme; adopt stronger CMM for sharks (eg fins attached);  To date, four CCMs namelyChina, Japan, Korea and Taiwan, continue to withhold data on the operations of their fleets in the high seas. This is an unacceptable situation that undermines the work of the scientific community and the credibility of management advice made available to the Commission andthwarts efforts to combat IUU fishing. In summary, it makes a mockery of this Commission. This is a serious breach in the obligations of CCMs as stipulated under article 5(b) & article 5(i) of the Convention.; year-round fad ban; closure to HS pockets to all fishing to compbat transshipments and IUU

reduce BET F; adopt easier to implement measures (eg FAD fishery closure, reduce effort) to end BET overfishing; do not let SKJ F increase; develop HCRs amd target ref points; urges CCMs to meet obligations around data submission on catch (LL HS specific); concerned w/ lack of WCPFC transparency; ensure observers collect FAD data; develop working group for FAD mgmnt; prohibit shark lines in LL + implement range of proven shark bycatch mitigation measures + stock specific ref points; limit LL capacity + ammend transshipment measure + limited entry of PS fleet to ensure capacity is not exceeded (w/mechanism to transfer capacity to developing countries)

adopt/implement T/LRPs; rebuild PBTfishery or suspend it; replace FAD closures with FAD set limits to combat BET F; stop PS capacity increase (esp w/FADs); dedicated CMM to reduce shark F + enforce existing measures; prevent CCMs from retaining/landing sharks if they had not submitted data on catch from prev year; adopt minimum standards for PSM inspections and provide support to developing states for implementation; ; vessels register with IMO; ban at-sea transshipments; establish procedure to list IUU vessels between sessions

World Wildlife Fund strongly commends the initiative of the Parties to the Nauru Agreement to establish and implement a TRP for the SKJstock in Parties to the Nauru Agreement waters. World Wildlife Fund also supports Japan’s development of an alternative CMM for an SKJ TRP recently presented for review by the WCPFC. Both proposals present valuable perspectives and strongcommitments to sustainability and precaution. We encourage a robust discussion about the proposedlevels for the TRPs in the different proposals and, upon compromising and selecting a candidate TRPat this meeting, support the application of that TRP throughout the WCPO. adopt and implement CMM for harvest control rules for all spp; target and lim ref points for all spp, observers to collect more data on FADs and shark bycatch; implement comprehensive shark CMM; shark catch/trade documentation scheme; ensure implementation req't for CITES are fully understood and planned for; ref points for all non-target spp; reduce BET F; adopt PBT CMM for rebuilding plan

stock assessments for billfishes; limit F on striped marlin and blue marlin; implement prohibition on Pacific billfish entering intl trade; countries to report dead discards and use circle hooks in LL; better recovery pan for PBT; FAD set limits to address BET overfishing; T/LRPs for SKJ; harvest control rules all spp; dedicated CMM for sharks incl. trace wire ban LL; ongoing IUU list; ban all at-sea transshipments; offer from IGFA to share data from rec fishery; need better data from  artisanal fishers in region

column2: International Union for the Conservation of Nature
column8: Collectively our organizations have thousands of staff working in offices and partner organizations in over a 100 countries and engage suppliers and provide advice to retailers, buyers and food service sectors regarding improvements in tuna sustainability. In addition, the undersigned industry organizations represent a considerable number of purse seine, longline and pole & line vessels active in WCPO tuna fisheries.

To strengthen cooperation with the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission in the scientific areas, in order to improve their work dynamic jointly, using similar assessment models for analyzing the status of all the shared stocks of tropical tunas in the Pacific Ocean as a whole...develop management measures such as a total closure of catches for the purse-seine fishery for skipjack, bigeye and yellowfin tunas, whereby the operation of the fleets is totally stopped; total Pacific closure in light of increasing effort; work in the development of a coordinated rebuilding and management plan for the bluefintuna stock

AFRF has worked to develop scientifically based limit reference points for North and South Pacific albacore with a focus on collaboration betweenthe Northern Committee and the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission to develop compatible reference points and harvest control rules for North Pacific albacore; develop HCR and T/LRP for ALB based on good science; need timley and complete data from Asian fleets; develop and utilize a Management Strategy Evaluation like ISC; does not want HS closed to ALB troll

new recovery plan for BET incl full ban on the use of FADs, a reduction in longline effort, and the closure of the high seas pockets to all tuna fishing is required; reduce fishing capacity and catch for ALB; full ban on transshipments; moratorium on PBT; interim reference points (until final ref points); strengthening the current shark finning measure (CMM 2014-05) to prohibit both methods of shark targeting (wire leaders and shark lines beneath buoys); strengthen 2010-07 to ensure sharks are fins attached; strenghthen WCPFC response to member non-compliance

establish ref points and HCRs that avoid adverse impacts on and ensure access by small-scale fishers; rebuilding plans for overfished stocks; improved data acquisition and reporting of target and bycatch spp; improved data collection and regulation of FADs; adoption of measures to reduce bycatch

elminate exemptions to CMM 2014-01 to address overfishing of BET; limit effort (fishing days) in SKJ PS; HCRs + target and lim ref points for all stocks; concerned with lack of operational data from some LL fleets - urges WCPFC to consider appropriate response for non-comppliance; concerned with lack of WCPFC transparency at meetings; need improved data on FADs; adopt measure to promote transparency in access agreements and joint venture agreements similar to IOTC and International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tuna; pushes for adoption of shark mitigtion methods; limit on LL capacity; encourages members to ratify 2009 Food and Agriculture Organization of UN PSMs agreemnt; establish limited entry to curtail capacity

adopt timelines for HCRs; rebuild PBT; end BET overfishing; manage FADs; reduce shark F; comprehensive management measures for sharks; prohibut ray retention; improve data collection for sharks; adopt minimum PSM standards; enhance effectiveness of IUU list; ban at-sea transshipments; strngthen CMS and increase transparency

HCR for all tunas; L/TRPs; adopt conprehensive shark CMM (many meaasures suggested); ref points for non-target spp; demonstrate sea turtle bycatch impacts are minimized through current CMM 2008-03 (update it as well); further monitoring and research of FADs; be more transparent about catch deliberations  of BET; implement binding and consolidated observer standards (ROP); support or endorse VMS and AIS to valifdate 100% observer  coverage on transshipments; ; longterm PBT recovery plan + size limit (>30kg) as temporary measure
Association for Professional Observers - Intl Observer Bill of Rights - best Practice Guidelines for Responsible Observer Programmes

we urge your government to support the full and timely implementation of the Work Plan for harvest strategies, including timelines to adopt appropriate biologically-basedtarget reference points, harvest control rules and the other elements of the harvest strategy approach, for skipjack, bigeye, yellowfin and south Pacific albacore tuna.
Doc re: NGO and other observer participating at WCPFC (and other IGO meetings)

eliminate the exemptions in the CMM and to adopt management measures that are effective and easier to enforce or a reduction in fishing effort, to meet theobjectiveofendingtheoverfishingofthebigeyestock.' limit PS fishing days to maintain SKJ around TRP; fully fund SKJ tagging program;  The WCPFC has made importantprogress adopting limit and target reference points for skipjack, and limit reference points for bigeye,yellowfinandSouthPacificalbacore,aswellasaworkplantoestablishHarvestStrategiesforkeyfisheriesandstocks;ReformitsCMSprocesssothataccreditedobserversmayattendtheworkinggroupmeetingsand information on CCM’s plans to address the areas of identified non-compliance bemadepublic: require non-entangling FADs; develop recs for FADs; increased data on FADs; fins attached for sharks; increase observer coverage for bycatch monitoring; ammend transshipment measure 2009-06; urge all members to ratify PSM agreement; strengthen compliance and approproate responses for non-compliance; Establish limited entry through closed vesselregistriesandtodevelopacommoncurrencytomeasurefishingcapacity; reduce LL capacity; SupporttheKobeIIIcallforcreatingmechanismstotransfercapacitytodevelopingcountries

Adopt elements of the harvest strategy approach that would specify measurable management objectives; target and lim ref points; 2-yr moratorium on PBT; management plan for FADs; adopt e-reporting and e-VMS; ban transshipments; science-based catch limits for sharks and improved data collection; complete ban of wire trace and shark lines; comp mgmnt plan for all sharks; prohibit retention of mantas/mobulas; PSM CMM; addition of IUU vessels bw meetings; improved transparency

signed by 26 SSC companies: we would like to suggest that the WCPFC adopts a set of interim target and limit reference points for all target tuna stocks and key by-catch species where these are not currently in place. These interim targets should be in place within the next 12 months.

The World Tuna Purse Seine Organization (WTPO) members, who are your partners indeveloping the tuna fishery so that this God given resource is utilized in an efficient andsustainable way, would like to express their concern on the following issues:1) Fishing Capacity Control: WTPO continue to support capacity control, with no exemption, in the convention area and in alloceans and the need to establish a capacity transfer arrangement in response to the aspirations ofSIDS to develop their respective fishery... 2) defintiion of FAD ; 3) While observers on board purse seine vessels have played significant roles in the management ofthe fishery there is a need to address issues on individual differences, misbehaviors andmisunderstanding of rules that can lead to misreporting and the need to act on every incident in atimely manner.

Support and endorse further implementation of CMM 2014-06 on Establishing a Harvest Strategy for Key Tuna Species in the WCPO consistent with proposed timelines; LRPs and TRPs for all stocks (incl. sharks); adopt Comphrehensive shark CMM; improved bycatch data collection from observers; ban wire tracers; fins attached; mobula/mantas to be considered as key shark spp; greater support for the Reg Obs Program; increased obs coverage in LL fleet; Support or endorse the use of VMS and AIS to verify and validate 100% observercoverage on all transhipments as well as supporting strong penalties andsanctions for violations;  Japan and Korea are obligated to provide bothhistoric and current operational data to the WCPFC consistent with several prior agreed CMMs datingback to 2005; CDS for PBT; recovery plan for PBT or moratorium

We strongly support the EU’s proposal aimed at safe, live release of manta and devil rays, and urge Parties to agree(accordingly) to prohibit retention, landing, sale, storage, and transshipment as well as harmful practices …; prohibit landing, retention,  transshippment of shark fins not attached to carcasses

column2: International Union for the Conservation of Nature
column8: We, the undersigned 58 scientists, call for a moratorium on commercial Pacific bluefin fishing until the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC)and Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission) improve their management of the species byending overfishing and adopting a basin-wide rebuilding plan with a science-based, precautionaryrebuilding target and deadline.

Submitted on behalf of 3 large food service companies:  Our companies purchase a variety of tuna products from member countries, and we recognize that the sustainability of tuna stocks is integral to our businesses as well as the health of the marine environment

strengthen reporting reqts to ensure all data are effectively collected; increased observer coverage for LL; health and safety for observers by developing robust standard; vessels using dFADs must provide access to raw data from buoys; reduce # of dFADs buoys and sets; make biodegradable FADs mandatory; assessment of LL fleet capacity; decrease F for BET nad YFT (esp juveniles); adopt rebuilding plan for PBT w/ catches excess to quotas paid back by responsible states; comprehensive shark CMM; prohibit retention of threshers, mobulas and mantas; ban wire leaders and sharks lines; failure to provide shark data = probition to retain sharks; phase out transshipments; 20% LL obsever coverage; adopt PSMs; penalties for non-compliance (no data = no fishing); improve transparency by removing barriers for IGOs and NGOs to attend compliance meetings; TRPs/LRPs and finalization of HCRs

continued progress on HCRs for all major stocks; recognize socio-economic importance of tropical tunas in developing and enforceable and effective bridging measure; improve monitoring and regulation of PS vessels (esp. FADs); reduce marine pollution (incl. FADs); reduce bycatch; improve observer safety and LL coverage; increase transparency in WCPFC compliance process

Our companies represent major seafood buyers that source seafood products from a diverse, international supply network. Our non-governmental organizations work in more than 100 countries and engage suppliers and provide advice to retailers, buyers and food service sectors regarding improvements in tuna sustainability.

We submit this letter on behalf of the undersigned companies, non-governmental organizations and fishing industry associations all who recognize that the sustainability of tuna stocks is central to businesses and livelihoods, as well as the health of the marine environment.

avoid increase in BET and YFT F; accelerate development of HCRs for tunas; incrase LL observer coverage; adopt science-based FAD mgmnt plan; increase transparency; better shark regs (fins attached)ammend transhipement measures CMM 2009-06); all members to ratify Food and Agriculture Organization of UN PSM agreement; reform Compliance Monitoring Scheme so obervers may attend meetings; establish limited entry through closed vessel registries to limit lL capacity; support Kobe III to transfer capacity to developing countries

bridging measures while transitioning to HCRs; TRPs and LRPs; adopt PBT rebuilding plan recommended by N Comm; improve FAD mgmnt; adopt e-reporting and monitoring; prohibit retention of threshers, mantas and mobulas; develop comrehensive shark CMM; ban transshipment at sea to ensure it doesn't contribute to IUU; improve effectiveness and transparency of CMS; adopt PSM CMM to regulate min standard in inpsection; urge CCMs to implement Flick the Switch; ammend 2013-10 ro require all vessels to have IMO#, update to IUU list between meetings

WTPO continues to follow, promote and support a no exemption on fishing capacity control in all areas; strongly recommends adoption of Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission definition for FADs; support Forum Fisheries Agency/Parties to the Nauru Agreement observer program; proposes the creation of a WCPFC working group to work with vessel operatorswith the objective of establishing new and improved systems and mechanisms that addresses all stakeholder concerns.; committed to the conservation and sustainable use of tuna resources and encourages WCPFC 14 to adopt sientifically based management easures suggessfully implemented in other RFMOs

HCRs and bio ref points for all stocks incl. sharks; adopt comprehensive shark CMM; improved shark data collection by observers; adopt risk-assessment shark stock assessment method; revise/replace CMM 2008-03 for turtles; improved observer safety standards; endorse VMS use and AIS to validate 100% observer coverage on transshipments; establish CDS for PBT; adopt tentative harvest strategy for PBT

Processors in Southeast Asia shall be contributing towards the example set by Thai Union. We shall implement reforms to address human rights, transshipment, longline and FADs with clear milestones by 2020. We shall continue to undertake open and transparent dialogue with key stakeholders; highlight that top 6 countries (Taiwan, China, Japan, Philippines, US & Korea) account for 85% of WCPO fleet and these elegations should work together toward full compliance to CMMs; WCPFC should consider issueing an official policy statemn on human rights and make appropriate steps to prevent such abuses; ban on HS transshipments; fully automated VMS (no manual reporting); 100%observer coverage; reduction on FAD sets and limit on number of FADs per vessel; transition to biodegradable and non-entanglish FADs; mandatory reporting on FADs; participation of handliners and P&L nations in decision making process; the Commission should set the lead in upholding the principles of inclusivity, responsibility, transparency and accountability in the decision making process. *6 PHILIPPINES BRANDS; 5 THAI BRANDS; 5 INDONESIA BRANDS*
The lack of data and accurate reporting on billfish catch is of particular concern

This letter is submitted on behalf of the undersigned companies, non-governmental organizations and fishing industry associations, all of whom recognize that the sustainability of tuna stocks is integral to businesses and livelihoods, as well as to the health of the marine environment. The companies represent major seafood buyers that source seafood products from a diverse, international supply network.

We know that WCPFC, with its 20 years of exemplary management experience, can greatly assist NPFC in its development and we look forward to more formal discussions for cooperation that will be mutually beneficial for both Commissions to deter and eliminate IUU fishing in our overlapping convention areas.

Agreement on the Conservation of Albatrosses and Petrels
column8: This paper reiterates for the WCPFC Commission the main points made in that paper, including ACAP’s continuing emphasis on exploring with our colleagues in Regional Fisheries Management Organizations, and others, ways to work together more effectively to reduce bycatch of albatrosses and petrels in fishing operations and improve the conservation status of these threatened seabirds.
I would like to stress the importance of cooperation between WCPFC and NPFC, which share responsibilities for the management of fisheries resources in a large part of the North Pacific Ocean.

The companies that have signed this letter represent major seafood buyers that source seafood products from a diverse, international supply network. The non-governmental organizations work in more than 100 countries and engage suppliers and provide advice to retailers, buyers and food service companies regarding improvements in tuna sustainability. The fishing industry associations represent a variety of gear types, including purse seine, longline, troll, pole and line, and handline vessels active in tuna fisheries worldwide.
